commentBody:
O O O! 

I "saw" the theme on my stone tablet.
This page's URL should be https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/24/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2024-12-25.html (no "s" after"puzzle").

Cute puzzle, appropriately themed.  I got the theme easily enough, but didn‚Äôt actually see the tree until the graphics revealed it. Unlike AI I am not much of a threat to be AWARE. The placement of the Os as ornaments and as the connecting points for the outline of the tree is a very nice touch.
A fun bedtime snack on Christmas Eve!

Constructor must be a regular yoga practitioner, because that was QUITE a stretch.  Decent enough little puzzle (if way too Christmas heavy) but that supposed image, really?  Strung from Os.  This is like one of those draw-the-cartoon instruction sets where after a few circles and dashes in the last step the character is supposed to magically appear fully formed.

I dunno, man.  Seems, well, "sus".

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Nice Christmas puzzle, and a "Merry Christmas!" to those who celebrate it. Hope your day has just as much excitement as you wish it to have, you get gifts that you like, and that anyone traveling gets to their destination(s) safely.

Other than wanting to try "O, tannenbaum" and quickly realizing that it wasn't going to fit, I wasn't snowed by this puzzle. Enjoyed the seasonal answers and appreciated the graphic at the end.

As far as trees, we have two artificial trees, small enough that we can store them in the limited storage space in our apartment, and are planning to use them for several more years or until they wear out. It also looks like there's not much of a market for real trees in our area‚Äîchains that sold trees in northern states are not selling them here, and I have not seen any tree lots at all.

Thanks, Jacob!

Loved the tree revealed at the end!  Thanks graphics people!

Based on the clues (and the date) I knew there would be a tree, but it was fun to see all the "O"s used!

I enjoyed the clues!

Needed to get to the column through a side door as the usual link didn't work.

Merry Christmas and Happy Hanukkah and Happy Holidays to all!
Merry Christmas, everyone!

The end graphic was a nice Xmas Eve treat.

Peace on earth, good will toward men, women, and animals.

Sweet puzzle.  Happy holidays to all.  In the Wordplay tradition of Christmas/holiday verse, here‚Äôs a modest offering:

Jesus dreamed big
Bigger than most
Though he was not want
To brag or to boast,
Turned water into wine
Rose from the dead
The guy was the son of God
Or so they said,
But that day he was born
Even he could not imagine
Pulling off a trick
That eluded Aladdin,
A Thursday puzzle with Rebuses galore
Black squares opening like doors
Crazy entries running in all directions,
Some even below the puzzle floor,
But most amazing of all
Surely the angels would adore
Instead of ‚ÄúBoo hiss!‚Äù in the Comments,
It was all ‚ÄúMore, More, More!‚Äù
I too loved the graphic at the end. I also enjoyed that the  O's of the tree were the only O's in the grid.

Avast, matey! A good chewy Wednesday that didn't roll over too easily. I would have liked to decorate the tree still further, with candy canes, globes and baubles, but that would have taken Sunday dimensions, and more could easily turn into too much. 

Good to see Pitt in there, my alma mater, and where I've taught a course or two with ESSAY TESTS, not that I've ever associated it with the Allegheny River. Pittsburgh was founded in the late 1740s when a contingent of Frenchmen journeyed down the Allegheny starting a little SE of Jamestown NY. Along the course of the river they embedded on its banks large leaden plaques declaring the surrounding land to be property of the king of France. A priest named Celoron, who accompanied the French, kept a journal that included an account of dining with Queen Aliquippa, a Seneca, and 27 others -- inside a hollowed-out tree! When they reached the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela, which forms the Ohio, they established a fort -- Fort Duquesne -- which the English burned down in November 1758, rebuilding it and renaming it Fort Pitt, after William Pitt, 1st Earl of Chatham. 

Re Jacob's notes: as a Jew who married a shiksa, we get a Christmas tree for its joyous odor, and the city has a recycling program that turns them into pine mulch for residents' gardens. But most organized religions have rites & beliefs abhorrent to us as modern liberals, which is not to dismiss all the good they do: charity, ethics, community, faith...
Our artificial tree is 44 years old and still going strong. So I think we're doing OK, environment-wise.

A puzzle I had to jump around on, but I never got stuck and had to stop jumping, and at the end, voila, a charming, lighted Christmas tree.  At our house we opened packages on Christmas Eve, so this was an appropriate gift, one I was delighted to receive.

Thank you Jacob McDermott.  You did indeed make my day.
Enjoyed this one! ALTHO it was admittedly pretty funny to see some of those words appearing in the middle of the Christmas tree‚Ä¶

"You own a Christmas tree farm?"
"Yes! But maybe I should branch out."

("Whatever works fir yew!")

This finally appeared, many hours after I posted it on yesterday's puzzle, so I'll post it again..  

One year we had a passel of kittens in the house and we forgot to coral them before we went to bed.  We were half asleep when we heard sinister little tinkling sounds from the living room, along with rustles as creaks, then c r a s h! as the whole Christmas tree keeled over.  We jumped out of bed and rushed to the disaster site just in time to see the perpetrators crawling out from under the branches and scampering in every direction.  We righted the tree and went back to bed, assuming they had learned their lesson,  but they were kitties, and the only lesson they learned was how exciting and fun it was to crash a tree, so of course they did it again.  We decided to wait until morning to deal with it.

Great final result! I love the animation. Props to Jacob for his vision and to the Times' IT staff for making it real.
Happy Christmas, all! üéÑ
Aw thanks for this! I came here hoping for just this sort of puzzle to wind down with after a busy day. Happy little graphic!  Merry Christmas and Happy Hanukah  everyone!!
Gorgeous and Christmassy thank you, loved it!
I didn't fully get the theme until it was complete, but it was cute and had a nice animation at the end. Merry Christmas to all
Lovely!

Merry Christmas üéÑ! Feliz Natal! Happy Hanukkah üïé 

Gee, I thought this was like a Monday‚Ä¶ until it wasn‚Äôt! I tried ‚Äúemigree‚Äù, ‚Äúescapee‚Äù, ‚Äúrefugee‚Äù ‚Äî all obviously wrong ‚Äî until the fairly obvious EVACUEE came to mind. 

SEDANS was a clever misdirection. I was worried that my alma mater would have been erroneously used for 12A ‚Äî it‚Äôs in Pennsylvania but nowhere near the Allegheny River or PITT. I was ready for a scrap until the correct answer emerged üòä

Regarding Christmas trees, there are no cut Christmas trees in Portugal, so it‚Äôs a moot point for us.  There are some potted trees in stores like Leroy Merlin (our Lowe‚Äôs). Otherwise, everyone buys and *keeps* artificial trees.

The Portuguese people have a very odd Christmas legend. Their Santa Claus is Pai Natal. It‚Äôs said that if butter is not left out for him, he will eat the toes of the little ones üò´üò≥üò≥ü´£.  Yikes!!!

Gotta go set out some butter‚Ä¶

Boas Festas! üéÅ

Awww‚Ä¶ sweet! Loved it! 

I think tradition is more important than any specific act. If your family‚Äôs tradition is to bring home a big pine from the tree farm, then that‚Äôs what will bring you joy. But if your family‚Äôs tradition is to bring down the big silver tree from the attic, then that can bring an equal amount of joy. The point is to do something together, do it with love, and do it over and over again. Tradition is the thing that builds both anticipation and memories, and it can be whatever you want it to be.

Whatever you may celebrate, be it Christmas, Hanukkah, or simply a day off from work, I wish everyone here a happy and joyous holiday.
I wish you all peace and joy. As I am spending Christmas in Wales I add Nadolig Llawen!  üéÑ
Thank you for @SIGNS! Maybe now I can sleep...

I accept that "near" is subjective but, according to Google, I'm the same order of magnitude distance away from the North Pole as Siberia and I would describe my proximity to it as "nowhere near".

Bah humbug, merry Christmas one and all.
Cute theme.  The inclusion of 14A, 20A, and 46A within the frame of the tree gave this a Fairytale of New York vibe and made me laugh.

To the constructor, I'm glad you're giving thought to the environmental effects of Christmas trees. I'm finding it increasingly objectionable for millions of perfectly healthy trees all over the world to be cut down and then discarded year after year for the sake of a tradition. I realize the issue isn't simple, but still it's time we got serious and addressed it.

Fun puzzle and a nice workout. Will confess that I didn't entirely catch on to the reveal until I was done and stared at the puzzle for a couple of minutes. That just made for a nice final 'aha' moment.

Two appropriate grid spanning answers dawned on me this morning. I'll just give you the possible clues: 

"We wish you..." (15 letters)

That answer appeared in 4 puzzles but never in the Shortz era. And even the 14 letter answer (dropping the 'a' from the front) was only ever in two puzzles. 

And...

"Have yourself ..." (21 letters)

Never been in a puzzle and not even in the Xword Info word lists. 

I'm done. 

....
For all the paper solvers out there, here's your present from Jim Horne at xwordinfo.com https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/25/2024 Season's greetings to all.

Oh tidings of gold stars and joy
Gold stars and joy
On tidings of gold stars and joy

üåç

As for [Red nose during wintertime, maybe?], I have always thought that a SYMPTOM is something one feels or experiences but differs from a ‚Äúsign‚Äù which can be seen or observed by others. So I would have called the red nose a sign of wintertime, not a symptom. https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/cancer-terms/def/symptom However, a broader definition applies here: https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/symptom

Yesterday I started my comment with ‚ÄúWhat a delightful puzzle ‚Äú. and that certainly describes this Christmas puzzle as well.  The graphics at the end took me completely by surprise, a lovely start to Christmas Day.  

Many thanks, Jacob.
Thank you, Jacob,  for a fun puzzle!  I loved the after finish graphic and how the 'O's were ornaments.  Merry day everyone, whatever you celebrate!
Loved the tree!üéÑThank you for a sweet first gift in the hush before joyful chaos to come. Blessings and peace, one and all.

What a lovely Christmas tree‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre a tree putter-upper or not. Which I am. Except not this year, what with all our tinsel etc. still crossing the North Sea. Which, in a way, has made our holidays more peaceful: There was no panic this morning of, ‚ÄúIs Gato still hogging the bed or is he downstairs chewing on the tree?‚Äù 

Normal cats break Xmas tree ornaments; they swing from Xmas tree branches; they topple trees with festive clatter. Gato strips them of their plastic bark. He also tries to eat the fake snow off them, which we learned after Sam's Great Flecked Xmas Tree Purchase Fiasco of 2022, but that‚Äôs ancient history, and besides the flecked tree never saw the outside of its box again, and besides I don‚Äôt like to talk about it, and neither does my husband because he pinched a nerve getting that monstrosity out of‚Äîand then right back into‚Äîits box, only to find that our living-room ceiling was not, in fact, 9 ft tall, which is the only part he will talk about‚Äîwith some relish, I might add (‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be an engineer to check the dimensions under the product description link, Sam, blah blah numbers blah‚Äù). I find such comments entirely superfluous post hoc. Besides, the 12 in. of the tree proved to be very pliable and, in fact, looked very avant-garde. Or avant-plafond at any rate. It'd've undoubtedly proved to be a conversation piece, had it not proved to be cat food first. Or, rather, a cat emetic. But I digress.)

Ah, memories.

Happy Holidays to you all!
nice one today with some clever clues--the reveal at the end was really cute! merry christmas everyone

RANDO thoughts:
‚Ä¢	I love the clues where what you think is a verb turns out to be a noun, such as [Votes for] for AYES, and [Handle things?] for AT SIGNS.
‚Ä¢	Thank you, @Mark Abe, for pointing out that the O‚Äôs of the tree are the only O‚Äôs in the grid.  That made this grid much tougher for Jacob to fill in, and bravo on that, Jacob!
‚Ä¢	When I saw the cross of CAT and CANARY, what sprung into mind was Sylvester.
‚Ä¢	Lovely PuzzPair¬© of the watermelon clue and PITT.
‚Ä¢	So witty of Jacob to come up with the idea of a literal O Christmas Tree.
‚Ä¢	I was given a stern talking to by a relative living in Phoenix after I pronounced the G in SEGUARO.

To all, a wonderful day, for whatever reason, and to Jacob, thank you for a sweet mood-lifter of a puzzle!

I hope the app had a fun animation. On paper, this was a bust. No way would I have ever thought to look at the Os. I tried looking for the nine letters of c-h-r-i-s-t-m-a-s, but that did not yield a tree image.

Guess I'm grinching into the day.
I'll look to Lewis for some happy thoughts.

This was an interesting solve for me, as I made one little tactical mistake:  not reading the entire revealer clue the first time.  I read "Holiday carol" and already had enough letters to slide O CHRISTMAS TREE into the grid without any problem, so I just moved on.

Then I saw the other bonus theme answers, GARLAND, LIGHTS, PRESENT and TINSEL, and I got the feeling that this was like the Monthly Bonus Puzzle in that there was a theme, and the goal for the constructor was just to throw as many related ideas into the puzzle everywhere.  (They have moved away from this idea in the Bonus Puzzles recently.)

Imagine my surprise when, upon completion, the tree overlay lit up!  I went back to the revealer to see what was going on, and I saw what I'd missed the first time.

Anyway, my opinion of the puzzle went up by several degrees at that point!

Solved on my iPad, so I got the Christmas tree graphic upon completion. But my device was muted. Was the music altered to match the puzzle‚Äôs theme?

Not easy to place just nine O‚Äôs in symmetric locations, along with four themers: LIGHTS, PRESENT, GARLAND, TINSEL. Nice Christmas Day puzzle!
Cute puzzle although ‚Äúaltho‚Äù was annoying. In the spirit of Christmas, I‚Äôll forgive it!
I thought this was a fun theme puzzle! I was pretty sure there was a tree in there but didn't figure out how until the end. Thanks for an enjoyable puzzle today and Merry Christmas to all!

Fun way to start my day‚Äôs festivities! I decided no tree for me this year and strung golden ribbons across my front window and hung my favorite ornaments, illuminated by a frame of Christmas lights and cranberry garlands. This will leave more room for my guests of all religions and denominations, but mostly one political persuasion,  to gather and celebrate.

That‚Äôs was a long way to go to say, I loved the pop up tree and the üÖæÔ∏è‚Äôs

Happy Christmas. Merry Hanukkah and Joyful Holidays to all.
That was pretty cool.

It's one of the rare occasions that the first night of Hanukkah and Christmas day overlap, and you choose to a Christmas-focused puzzle? It strikes me as shortsighted. Was the tree cool? Sure. Could you have made it a little more -- multicultural? Definitely.
Thank you for a perfect Christmas present.
Just celebrating that for the first time an illustration in the grid did not block the ‚Äúsystem‚Äù from declaring ‚Äúsolved‚Äù and awarding a gold star ‚Ä¶for the tree topper maybe? Happy Christmas!

lovely puzzle though I wish the O's hadn't needed the pejorative 30A.
  I am tentatively on team Live Tree on the grounds that most of them are deliberately planted and spend an average of 7 years sequestering carbon before harvest. But a Christmas tradition of being mindful is a great one to start.
Here's something from the Farmers' Almanac but hardly by a disinterested person [astride my hobby horse of keeping the correct meaning of that word alive!]:
"These trees around us do so much work, storing carbon dioxide and emitting fresh oxygen.¬†Christmas trees also stabilize soil, protect water supplies, and provide refuge for wildlife while creating scenic green belts. They have a¬†positive impact on the environment¬†that you can feel good¬†about"
Thanks, Jacob McDermott! I'm stuck at home this year due to illness, and your puzzle made the day seem a little more like Christmas. Well done!
So good! Put a big smile on my face. üéÑ

I'll have to break out the red and green markers to make this cute puzzle a little more festive.  I helped a REFUGEE  in the SW and nearly felled the TREE.  Saved by the sailor's shout...

"Outfits" could be EQUIPS, if a verb.  Could be TROOP if a noun.  And, I suppose, if you pay a lot of attention to clothes, it might suggest GET-UPS (though usually that's not overly complimentary!  That corner took me as long as the rest of the puzzle.

And isn't a RASP a rather hefty tool to bring to "shaping" your wood-carving?  
DHubby participated by giving me the U in Leopold AUER--was that entry/clue a gift for our Andrzej?  

O TANNENBAUMoops!  who you callin' a SUCKA?
Oh well.
  Frohe Weinachten!

Fun puzzle with a cool graphic. I didn't get the 'O' until I read the comments, but I'm still working on my first cup of coffee.

Team live tree here if the tree comes from a tree farm. That makes it a crop, a renewable resource, and an income source for the farmer, plus the wildlife haven and carbon sink others have mentioned. Artificial trees are plastic, which is bad in so many ways, and, apparently, a cat emetic, too.

Merry Christmas, Happy Hanukkah, Happy Kwanzaa, belated Happy Solstice, and if you celebrate a winter holiday I haven't mentioned, Happy Holidays!
As to the Christmas Tree debate, I think Jim Gaffigan, a practicing Catholic, says it best: https://youtu.be/_uNapsV2L3E?si=hG0SI_-vmDeNQReO

What a fun puzzle! Thank you, Jacob McDermott! I had an errant "O" until I realized I had spelled TANDEM wrong (TANDOM; whoops!). Trying to make CLEAVE into CLEOVE to make the trees sides match didn't work at all. üòÜ 

Happy holidays to all!

What a fun puzzle with an adorable animation to wrap it up! We - okay, I, since my husband tends to go along agreeably with whatever I have to say in this arena - have had a fair amount of (artificial) Christmas tree uproar in the last couple of years, thanks to moving and hospital stays and hard-to-ignore summertime tree discounts etc., but ours is up and tall and lit and decorated and awaiting only gifts and a collar to wrap the base, which I will finish shortly; my sister is a nurse hard at work for the day, so we will do most of our celebrating tomorrow (and I will be grateful for the extra 24 hours in which to cram tasks :-)

Merry Christmas! Happy Hanukkah! Joyous and healthy holidays to all my fellow puzzlers.

Someone just did something lovely for me this Christmas morning and the puzzle has gone right out of my head.  Oh, yes, I remember now -- it had something to do with my being urged to connect squares and draw something.  You all know I never do that sort of stuff.  But I'm sure that if I did, what I would end up with is a tree.  I'll go to Rex's column now and see what it's supposed to look like.

Just between you and me, though, this has given me an idea -- no, not the drawing a tree part -- for a Christmas-themed puzzle for next year.  I think it's a crunchy idea if it can be made to work.  Alas, I will not have the invaluable puzzle knowledge and keen insights and grid-making brilliance of my usual collaborator who is in the midst of a boycott of the NYT for political reasons and refuses to submit there "for the foreseeable future."  So I shall have to find a new collaborator.

But at least I have a fresh theme idea that I like.  Sometimes they seem so darned slow in coming...

Happy holidays to everyone.

Though I appreciate all the arguments for choosing real trees over fake, part of me still feels a loss in the felling of a tree, the ending of a life. For now, I‚Äôll stick with my faux fir for a few more seasons.
Nice graphic on solving. Merry Christmas, everyone.

I'm on team "no tree." 

However, it's worth noting that, when I was a kiddo, we always had a live tree. And I really mean "live" - once you cut a tree, it's not really alive any more. It would more accurately be termed a "dying tree." 

Our Christmas trees were dug up, roots and all, by my father and, when I was older, by him and my brother and me. We would go out before the ground was frozen and dig one up.  He would encase the roots in burlap and it would sit in a tub in our cold garage until it was time to set it up indoors. It would be moved into the house, tub and all, and a decorative fabric draped over the galvanized tub.

Once the holidays were over, it would be returned to the garage until Spring, when we would plant it on the hill behind our house. I would estimate we had a success rate of well over 50% -- probably close to 75%. Some trees did succumb to the trauma, but it's still a lot less trauma than having the trunk sawn through. 

We eventually had a pretty substantial and attractive grove of mostly blue spruces on that little knoll. 

I returned to that house a few years ago, over 50 years after my parents sold the house, and they are still there, easily seen because all trees growing naturally in the area are deciduous. Other than these tall blue spruces. No, they are not propagating, so they are not invasive (and blue spruce habitat is less than a mile away). 

So, put me on either team "no tree" or on team "truly live tree."

Merry Christmas, one and all!

I loved this puzzle! Thank you!

Aaaand ‚Ä¶ we used to cut trees, (we lived in a national forest where this was allowed) and then had a fake  tree for several years. (Harder to put together!) New town, new partner, new-old tradition: For the past decade, we‚Äôve gone to the same tree farm to cut our tree, and then to lunch at a perfect diner called The Fork in the Road.

Peace to all my fellow puzzlers on this holiday.

I thought we were supposed to worry that A.I. would become SkyNet.

Real trees for me, but I may be biased; my mom's cousin and his family own and operate a tree farm up in Pennsylvania. Yes, we get a discount.

Fun puzzle, and the placement of the Os in the graphic did not diminish the quality of the entries. Merry Christmas!
Great puzzle. And as long as you have kids, go with the live tree. Some traditions are worth preserving in their analog state.

Adding in to the cut tree versus fake tree debate: cut trees are a renewable resource and tree farms themselves provide many benefits (social and environmental). Think of all the live trees that exist as a result of cut tree purchases! Plus the cut trees can be recycled in many ways after Christmas (firewood, wood chips, mulch) or composted. Fake trees are often produced overseas and then used for only 2-3 years before winding up in a landfill where they basically will ‚Äúlive‚Äù forever. Using a fake tree for at least 10-15 years might (that‚Äôs ‚Äúmight‚Äù) be better in terms of environmental costs in the long run, but few are made well enough to last that long.

I got a little worried when I was going through the across clues and didn't see any holiday theming, but then I looked around a bit more and saw what was going on. Great theme idea, and the perfect difficulty for a nice relaxed solve. Hope everyone has a great Christmas!

A very cleverly constructed puzzle with a great reveal! Evocative of the feeling one gets when a real tree is lit for the first time. I was greatly amused when I saw that the O's represented ornaments. Thanks, Jacob, for all that went into constructing this crossword!
A fairly straightforward puzzle otherwise, but took me two minutes longer than my best time for a Wednesday.

Breakfast with kids, grandkids & 3 dogs. Presents opened. Nice puzzle just finished. Nap approaching. Dinner to come with candles glowing. Not a bad day  with family all safe in "America the Beautiful." Let's spend 2025 with less complaining & lots more helping. Merry Christmas to all...........!
The clue for 7 across has a typo/error.  Too many of the word "you".

'Arguably,' ornaments and lights are all the better decoration of a Christmas Tree needs. Some prefer the addition of Tinsel. But all that decoration AND a garland is as unnecessary as it is unattractive -- and 'suggests' the decorator is of the gauche school.

When I was a tot, back in the 40‚Äôs, our tree stand was also a music box and built so that the tree holder revolved while the hand cranked music box played Stille Nacht and Adeste Fideles.  It came over to the US with the great grandparents from Bavaria in the 1890‚Äôs.  A real tree would have been too heavy for the mechanism and so our artificial tree made of mostly wire, paper and cardboard did the honors.  Decked out with equally old glass ornaments and icicles and strings of electric lights, yes it was wired, it was in our eyes beautiful.  We also followed the German custom of presents on Christmas Eve followed by midnight church.  The music box/stand was inherited by an older cousin so I have no idea if it is still in use these many decades later but I will never forget the enchanting way it sang and revolved.

I know I am in the minority, but I am Jewish and personally don't celebrate Christmas. It would have been nice to have an escape from everything Christmas even in my lovely morning routine puzzles üò≠ like, I get it, I understand why things are the way they are. But still. I mean Hanukkah starts this evening, why not a Hanukkah and then Kwanzaa themed puzzle in the subsequent days! That would be fun, we could get to learn about other holidays.

Loved the graphic. 
Fun puzzle. 
Hope everyone is having a lovely Christmas Day.
I have one of the few Civics that's a coupe.  Looks kind of cool I guess but the big doors are kind of a nuisance
Very festive üéÑ
I loved this puzzle. So festive and fun! Thanks for the Christmas treat!
Great puzzle! Thanks for the work.
Fun!

In the grand scheme of things, Christmas trees probably have as much effect on the health of our environment as they have on the health of the religion with which they are associated. (We always have a tree that you cleave from its base, the kind that is a sucka of watah.)

Best wishes to all.
And be sure to avoid artificial Boxing Day sales.
Well done Mr. McDermott on a fine, fun, and festive puzzle.  Thank you.  Merry Christmas and Happy, Healthy New Year to all.

Momentarily Naticked by MARA/ORA. R seemed right, though.

I thought M**** went the way of the r-word due to ties to eugenics.

Fun puzzle and enjoyed the tree at the end. 

As for what kind of tree? Whatever you like! I‚Äôm feeling very nonjudgmental these days. There are infinite ways to celebrate the season if you do celebrate it. Express yourself. Do something different each year. 

We no longer have kids at home so we get a little tree from Whole Foods. Works great for us. And then we compost it. 

Happy Hanukkah for those who celebrate it, starting tonight!

Well! Spent an eleven-and-a-half hour day at the workplace, hosting (and for four hours, flipping omelets for) the fighting Panthers (football team); then came home to the puzzle--what a coincidence.

In our living room, we have growing a tree-sized pencil cactus, *Euphorbia tirucalli*. We decorate it with lights and ornaments for Christmas, and lay our presents below it. Gather round, all, and sing:

"O Poison Tree, O Poison Tree/
How toxic are thy branches!"

Merry Christmas to all who celebrate--and Peace to those who don't--and, since it's after sunset--Happy Hanukah!

Completed this while watching the second-best Christmas movie in the world, Die Hard 2: Die Harder! üòÄ

I'll give you one guess for the first. Happy Christmas, crossworders!! üéÖüèæ
I‚Äôm glad other people enjoyed this puzzle. üôÇ

As someone with a decent solve rate (82%), who doesn't cheat or continue trying after finishing a puzzle incorrectly (side note: why is the solve rate by day not available?), I am fascinated that the "tricky clue" that I fail to solve is NEVER a clue mentioned in the days' summary.  

I mean NEVER, and rarely is the clue explained in the hundreds of comments.  


Today's example is "cataracts" which I am supposed to know doesn't just refer to the extremely common eye ailment, but also is an obscure reference to waterfalls.  

How is that not tricky?

Following up.  Not one of the 182 comments referenced CATARACTS as being a tricky clue.  

Some mentioned Rita Ora as being tricky, which to experienced solvers, occurs fairly often. 

But choosing to clue cataracts as a waterfalls something I have never seen, nor was I aware of the term.  Yet, nobody saw it as tricky. 

Is everyone just cheating, and it has become so common that it is not even worth discussing?

If one looked hard enough, you could find this so-called theme occurring serendipitously in other puzzles...... Other note: there is a world of difference difference between "unapproved pharmaceutically" and "unapproved *use* pharmaceutically"

But the stone tablet doesn't turn green. 
We print solvers must use our imagination.
Fine by me.
I hope other solvers get to the column by coming down the chimney until the front door opens.

@Barry Ancona 

That would just soot you fine.  "Happy Holidays," she said with a smile.
@Barry Ancona I hope you chiseled the tree in on yours! :) Happy Holidays!!!

For everyone, there are three ways to get to the puzzle: https://www.nytimes.com/spotlight/daily-crossword-column https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily I just have bookmarks for all three. A wrong link shouldn't hold you up for long.

@Richard 
In everyday speech ‚Äúsign‚Äù and ‚Äúsymptom‚Äù are more or less interchangeable, but in medicine you are correct: a symptom is something unobservable that a patient reports, like pain or dizziness. A sign ‚Äî like the red nose here ‚Äî is something that can be perceived without talking to the patient.

@Robert Schwartz 
Not to beat a dead symptom to death, but this has come up before in this column. As you say, the distinction between symptoms and signs is who is perceiving them.  But symptoms are not always *unobservable*. A patient may come in with a chief complaint of a rash that they have noticed, that is their symptom. The doctor sees the rash, so it is a sign. The rash can be either a symptom, a sign, or both.

@Lewis 

Yes, another example of English taking a foreign word and doing stuff to it, in this case, the pronunciation.

SAGUARO, properly pronounced in Spanish, has the same intervocalic G as the word AGUA, which means the point of articulation in the back of the mouth is barely grazed rather than occluded as is in initial G or any English G.  This variant sound of g, which is not found in English, is represented by linguists as […£].  The fact that the following U minimizes the G further doesn't help the fact that English speakers cannot hear it at all and take it as a silent G.

So they pronounce the cactus or the national park  /s…ôÀàw…ëÀê.r…ô/ (as per Cambridge and M-W), using the definitively un-Spanish schwa as the first and last vowels as well.  This is as wrong as pronouncing the middle of the word with a full English G.

I wonder how your Arizonan friend pronounces Turkish President Erdoƒüan's name.
Huh!  Very interesting.  Thank you for this, Steve!
